[quote=The Narrator][h3][i]"Once again teetering on that terrible precipice..."[/i][/h3][/quote] 

DD2 is a schizophrenic sequel. The first game was released nine years ago but remains a must-play, a radical indie title with a killer artistic direction ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/stscylla/recommended/262060/]here's my review/introduction[/url]). 

After its critical and commercial success, Red Hook could have milked their playerbase and simply packaged some new content as a fully-priced sequel. It's pretty standard practice and would have been an easy sell to players who wanted more of the same. But these devs don't settle for easy. For the record the final expansion of DD1 added an unexpected PvP mode - for free.  

With DD2 they decided to redo all visuals in 3D, update the combat system, break down the progression structure and build two roguelite modes. 

[quote=The Narrator][h3][i]"What is it, then, that gazes back so intently from the abyss?"[/i][/h3][/quote] 

The new 3D visuals retain the gorgeous art style of the original game and fix its issues: body proportions are much healthier, depth feels better and animation transition make it all look smooth.  

The updated combat system has dropped traditional stats such as Accuracy and Armor, which were responsible for weird RNG spikes like failing three consecutive attacks at 90% accuracy. DD2's battle flow revolves around positive and negative tokens, such as Blind and Guard, which are applied or cancelled by combat actions. The result feels less random and more predictable, which is helpful in a tactical game, but harder to pick up: new players must first learn all tokens. Fortunately there's a quick reference guide available in the options. 
 
Veterans will also note that stress no longer acts as a second health pool, but impacts a number of other mechanics such as relationships. 

[quote=The Narrator][h3][i]"The sumtotal of violent equation, unfavourably rounded down!"[/i][/h3][/quote] 

Ditching the permanent progression of the original game, DD2 introduces two roguelite game modes: Confessions and Kingdoms. 

Confessions are gauntlet runs with multiple regions to cross and a different final boss in each of the five difficulty levels. You need to carefully build a party of 4 heroes as opportunities to replace any casualty are very limited.  

Progression between runs is made of permanent unlocks of skills, paths (subclasses) and trinkets (gear), which open up new synergies and tactics. If you want to turn your Leper into a killing machine, equip the Goading Gargoyle trinket and choose between the Monarch and the Tempest paths. If you need him to tank, go down the path of the Poet and make sure to take the Withstand and Solemnity skill upgrades. 

Kingdoms offer longer runs against one of three factions: the beast clan, the witch coven and the cursed courtiers. Rather than a party of four, you control the full roster of heroes spread on a world map. The goal is to simultaneously defend local inns and keep a mobile task force to complete a series of quests. 

Both modes benefit from mod support and a range of settings to tailor the experience to your liking. As much as I enjoy upgrading my heroes and inns in Kingdoms, I find runs in this mode to feel rather long and repetitive. Confessions have a narrower focus but get to the point. 

In any case, DD2 is a poison I prefer taking in small doses. This game is equally intoxicating and deadly. The challenge posed by the final bosses is honestly beyond my current skill. But I've faith in the Narrator's words. 

[quote=The Narrator][h3][i]"Persistence will overcome even the greatest of threats."[/i][/h3][/quote] 

In 2025 DD2 received a burst of updates: the Kingdoms mode and its three factions, the Inhuman Bondage DLC with the Abomination and the Catacombs, and a bunch of class balancing and interface polishing patches. It's my nominee for the Labor of Love award. You can check [url=https://store.steampowered.com/steamawards/nominations/2025/76561197992891947?k=16186207227725582]my other 2025 Steam Awards nominees here[/url].

This game is what I would call, an exemplary Darkest Dungeon sequel. I see a lot of people have a lot of grievances with the way this game plays, but I would say, Redhook deserves credit and praise for trying to differentiate this game from DD1. If people want to play a "true" sequel, then they can play Black Reliquary whenever that comes out. I feel that the Rougelite implementation has been done incredibly well, and it's important for games to innovate on sequels, especially within reason, which RedHook did IMO. The game looks fantastic, feels great to play, is a pleasure to listen to (SFX and Music wise), and overall, just a fun time, unless you're getting Darkest Dungeon'd, which happens. I also have to give more props to RedHook for the extensive class reworks, new content, and updates they've been consistently pushing out for the past two years since launch. Besides that, not much else to say, DD2 still feels like a Darkest Dungeon game and it's good as f.

Also, rest in peace Wayne June. You brought something to this game that can never be replicated.

I really love this game even though it is obviously not perfect. The visual style, the combat, and theory-crafting synergistic teams are all incredible. I don't fault it for being different from DD1. I like that they went with a divergent and ambitious sequel instead of resting on their laurels. That being said, there are some things prospective buyers should know if you're on the fence.

Beginning the game on a fresh account will be very difficult. Unless you are already extremely familiar with the mechanics, you will likely lose repeatedly while unlocking necessary progression with each run that will eventually make the game manageable (it's roguelike, duh). You should only buy this if you are intent on steamrolling through early setbacks and getting your progression up. But even after your progression is up, the game is still hard. There are many difficulty modifiers I haven't tried because even the basic difficulty is pretty challenging in my opinion. 

The game launched with a mode called Confessions, which is essentially Slay The Spire type runs with DD combat. It also has narrative elements and really cool bosses, but at the end of the day is kind of paltry as a standalone offer. Clearly Red Hook agreed, which is why they created the Kingdoms game mode later. Kingdoms is closer to the persistent base building of the first game, with a longer gameplay loop than Confessions. Having both Confessions and Kingdoms to play is a better value proposition, but also bifurcates the game into two modes with no relation to one another, which sort of highlights the confused direction of DD2. 

This part is not necessarily relevant to prospective buyers, but hero balance has also been a persistent problem with this game. From early access onwards, I feel Red Hook did not have a firm grasp on their balancing approach to heroes. This is somewhat understandable, considering the heroes are much deeper than their DD1 counterparts. But over the years, Red Hook has spent an inordinate amount of time balancing these heroes to make up for early mis-steps that they could have spent in other ways. The Steadfast Stewards updates were very cool, but in the end applied seemingly different design philosophies to different characters as time went on, leading to inconsistent choices across the roster. For example, giving some Leper moves extra actions, which is a very powerful mechanic that could have really helped other characters in the past. As of writing, the entire hero roster is still not quite balanced, but hopefully the vibrant modding scene will fix that. 

Overall I've had a ton of fun with this game despite some annoyances over the years. It's one of my favorite turn based games ever, and I hope Red Hook learns lessons from it that improve the development of their future games.

[h1]Comparisons To The Original[/h1]
If you're new to Darkest Dungeon and are unsure which game to buy or have played the first game and are on the fence about buying 2, read on as I've attempted to list some similarities and key differences between the two games below, although with more of a focus on 2 as this is a review of the second game and not the first.

[h2]Similarities[/h2]
[list]
 [*] Combat is turn based, with your group of 4 heroes pitted against 4 enemies.
 [*] Turns in combat are decided by the speed of each character present, with faster characters acting first.
 [*] Position determines what abilities a character may use and who they may target, for example Hellion's Iron Swan ability requires her to be at the frontmost rank and may only target an enemy in the 4th position.
 [*] Dead heroes and enemies leave behind corpses that take up a position in combat.
 [*] Heroes may equip alternate abilities allowing them to fill different roles, only so many abilities may be equipped at once.
 [*] Heroes may equip up to two trinkets providing various benefits and maluses depending on the trinket.
 [*] Heroes posses both a health bar and a stress bar, where enemies only possess health. Reaching 0 health means getting put into the "Deaths Door" state, afterwards any point of damage has a chance of landing a deathblow and killing the character, healing above 0 health will cause the character to leave Deaths Door and act as normal. Maxing out the stress meter gives a character a chance at having a meltdown/outburst of some form, taking damage and typically carrying some malus that varies depending on the outburst, or steeling themselves and becoming resolute, healing them and reducing stress.
[/list]

[h2]Darkest Dungeon 1[/h2]
[list]
 [*] Features an almost X-Com like focus on building and managing a wide roster of characters, death means the loss of a character and having to train a replacement.
 [*] A run takes the form of a prolonged campaign, with progression between missions involving upgrading your town to better equip and maintain your heroes, with the ultimate goal being to get your heroes strong enough to tackle the titular darkest dungeon and win the run.
 [*] Characters exist as classes, you can and will have multiples of the same character in your roster and a party may double up on the same class.
 [*] Missions involve dungeons crawls with varied layouts, as you traverse each dungeon you are met with various encounters such as interactable curios that give different results depending on the choices made/items used or combat encounters.
 [*] Resource management is crucial to keep your heroes topped up in missions so as not to lose a war of attrition.
 [*] Features a separate PvP mode, the Butcher's Circus. I cannot speak on how active this mode is at the time of writing.
[/list]

[h2]Darkest Dungeon 2[/h2]
[list]
 [*] Features two game modes, Confessions and Kingdoms.
 [*] Confessions plays like a more typical roguelite, with meta progression between runs. Permanent unlocks are acquired between runs using Candles obtained throughout the course of a run, speaking from experience the grind is pretty quick as so long as you're making good progress a failed run will still net you enough Candles for a large number of unlocks and upgrades.
[*] Kingdoms runs are self contained, in that unlocks from confessions and other Kingdoms runs do not apply, and take the form of longer campaigns (albeit still significantly shorter than a typical Darkest Dungeon 1 run) where you move your party and other heroes around a map, defending and upgrading Inns (acting as your various bases) with the ultimate goal being to progress a quest and defeat a campaign dependant boss. At the time of writing three different campaigns are available, with different unique enemy factions and quests.
[*] Missions in both game modes have you travel along branching paths between various points of interest and potentially facing encounters as you travel. Your party members may indicate a preference for certain paths, rewarding you with a stress heal or taking stress damage if you follow or ignore their suggestions, and heal passively as you travel.
 [*] The game features a narrower but deeper roster where each character is an individual (the presets forms of classes from the first game alongside some newcomers) with a large amount of unlockable alternate abilities/customisations and whose backstory is explored throughout the Confessions game mode (doing so permanently unlocks new abilities for the hero). In Kingdoms, alternate abilities are instead purchased at Inns with the required upgrade.
 [*] Heroes possess paths (subclasses) that you unlock through progression in Confessions, or again at upgraded Inns in Kingdoms, that can drastically change how they play and allows for varied team comps and synergies, making up for the inability to double up on classes.
 [*] Death in Confessions means losing the hero for the rest of the run and receiving a replacement hero if you make it to the next inn, this replacement is selected randomly from the heroes you have not yet lost this run. Death in Kingdoms is configurable at the start of a run, permadeath is on by default on most difficulties, however it may be configured so that a dead hero respawns at a penalty or a fresh untrained replacement spawns after losing a hero.
 [*] Heroes form relations, rewarding you with positive boons such as a heal or DoT removal when using specified abilities or randomly attacking alongside or defending eachother at good relations and at bad relations debuffing themselves or eachother when using specific abilities or doing/taking stress damage. These relations are influenced by the choices made by the player throughout a mission as well as items used while resting.
 [*] After a successful mission in Confessions you arrive at an Inn where you may spend mastery to upgrade abilities, purchase equipment and consumables, upgrade and repair your coach, and use Inn items to heal, buff, or improve the relationships of your heroes.
 [*] As previously mentioned, Inns play a different more important role in Kingdoms and are only located at specific points on the map. If you travel to a location without an Inn, you will instead make camp which allows you to use consumables as you would an Inn but does not feature a merchant or upgrades and has the possibility of a surprise ambush, as in the first game.
 [*] Does not feature the Butcher's Circus.
 [*] Combat is similar to the first game, but features new tokens and mechanics such as the combo token which sets up for secondary effects on the abilities of various characters and enemies. Stall tactics like healing have had restrictions placed on them so that they may only target characters under certain conditions, such as being below 33% health or having specific tokens applied.
 [*] In combat consumables are equipped to and carried by party members in a dedicated slot, with each character able to carry only one type of item at a time (they may carry multiple of the equipped item however). Using consumables does not take an action.
[/list]

[h1]Should You Buy?[/h1]
If you're coming from Darkest Dungeon 1 and find that your favourite parts of it were the wide roster management and the dungeon crawling, and are explicitly looking for more of that gameplay then Darkest Dungeon 2 may not be for you.
If your favourite elements of Darkest Dungeon 1 were the combat and strategy, or are looking to immerse yourself in more of the games lore and setting then I can thoroughly recommend 2.
If you're new and were intimidated by the longer campaigns and roster management of 1, you may find 2 a bit easier to get into.

Okay, let's make one thing clear. First Darkest Dungeon, is NOT a rogue-like. It has too much intergrity between each dungeon and the default game mode of it is literally called "Campaign". The tag on steam was wrong. It's a rogue-LITE at best and it's still a stretch for my taste.

Darkest Dungeon 2 on the other hand, the Rogue-like/lite fits right in the spot. I get why they did do it, but it kinda takes away the infamous, irreversable consequences to every action you have commited in the first iteration. Losing a run in DD2 doesn't feel significant. You just retry and get better with whatever candles you have collected during previous attempts. Sure, losing memories and qirks on your characters sucks to lose, but they still come back 90% of unlocks still on them, as the progress is permanent. It just doesn't feel right.

Now, despite the last paragraph, here is why I actually really enjoy this game:

-Combat. Darkest Dungeon 2 has took the already established via trail and error combat system of original and improved upon it. They even took daze mechanic from the Butcher's circus, which was definitely a good choice and a segway to the exhibit A.
 The nerf of stun. It was far too easy to best the dungeons in the first game by just spamming stuns and bullying 
the adversaries. Here, you need to spend (in most cases) at least two turns, just to take one from the opposition.
And daze itself isn't too useless either. Change was imperative. 
 Exhibit B. New skills and paths. I adore the amount of flexibillity classes have, often focusing on a specific playstyle, not only improving it in the long run, but also pulling twists on them. Really hits the spot in case you lose a character and you need to fill in the gap. It's a lot of fun and gives room for experimentation.
 Exhibit C. Mechanics. Tho I'm not entirely sold on the tokens replacing majority of buffs, it does help to keep the flow of the game faster, more likely letting you complete the run in a single sitting. When it comes to gimmicks for the fights, I would describe them as understandable in the majority, not making you study entire wiki so that you may have a shot at winning against bosses. They are new, refreshed or revamped.

-Lore Extention. While the plot of DD2 in general is rather confusing for where it takes place, why does it all happen and how is it connected with the prequel. At least we get a look on the world outside of the hamlet. It absolutely nails expanding of Character's backstories tho, especially Abomination's, which I won't elaborate on for the sake of not spoiling. Point is, that we get to learn more about our heroes' personallities and tell reasons why are they the way that they are. Instead of putting archetypes into these characters for our own headcanons, seeing them as a base colored canvases, Red Hook made them into fully finished pieces of art, where we see ourselves in some of them.

-Atmosphere. Keeps the same mood and aesthetic from the predecessor. It's amazing how well they transferred from 2d to 3d with their action comic artstyle. The special effects tendfolds from what we had, giving us satifaction and thrill with each attack. Constant voice lines of our irreplacable Narrator, Wayne June (R.I.P, you legend [*]) are simply a perfection. Not much more to say, 10/10. Frankly, he's the reason why I always improve on my english vocabulary and learning the most obscure synonyms I can find.

-Community Feedback. These people listen to us and give what we want. New characters, Old characters brought back, so the enemies, Character update for those in need, and best for last, Kingdoms Mode. The throwback to the original game, where you can't just restart the run and try again where you last reached the checkpoint. This is why Indie studios are the best. We want Leper's Monarch path to actually exist? Boom, now it's the best late game option! You miss the nostalgic campaign aspect from 10 years ago? Boom, enjoy new game mode, coming in three flavours! More skins (especially for Bounty Hunter)? Say no more, chum.

  To summarize, Darkest Dungeon has been my favorite series for a long time. I've exploded when The sequel was released and felt little disappointed when the first early access came out, but I got over it and so did the game. And while there's still plethora of issues with the second game, They are mere nauseances in the bigger picture. Nothing's flawless and I'm ready to forgive those hiccups. We shouldn't judge the game sequel purely by comparing it to the original, because it's not the same game.

Darkest Dungeon 2 is a game which I feel scratches that itch for a turn-based roguelike. The combat is a significant improvement from the original game, and allows for so much more customizability. 
The introduction of hero paths have made each hero so much more replayable and adds a significant level of adapatablity to each hero, making characters fit into teams they wouldn't have before. Furthermore the way buffs and debuffs are applied has changed with the introduction of the new token system, which uses tokens in place of generic text based stat changes.

The two modes, kingdoms and confessions, allow for a variable gameplay type where kingdoms plays a bit similarly to the traditional Darkest Dungeon and confessions being the full roguelite mode of the game. 

The artwork puts the first game to shame with the introduction of better 3D attack animations and the use of the iconic Darkest Dungeon art style in a 3D format. Overall the game looks stunning with each monster and boss looking very distinct. The sound and music design is also improved over the first game making each area feel distinct.

Overall I feel that Darkest Dungeon 2 is a good game with fun mechanics, but one thing to keep in mind is that THIS IS NOT DARKEST DUNGEON. The sequel is more of a spiritual successor rather than a proper sequel, you could call it a spin-off if it fits. Don't expect the same experience as the first game and remember that this can be a signifcantly shorter experience over the first, depending how willing you are to attempt the completion of confessions or kingdoms.

Darkest Dungeon 2 is one of those games I never asked for a prequel to, yet still eagerly jumped into the moment it came out.

My first impression of this series goes all the way back to 2013, back when the Rock Paper Shotgun site “existed” (yes, they’re dead to me at this point). I remember seeing an article about this very peculiar-looking game with a striking art style and a buzzword I had never seen used as a mechanic before: “Stress.”

It took me a couple tries with the first game to understand what the developers were going for. The core mechanic of Darkest Dungeon is all about managing a team of heroes through brutal dungeons while wicked music and a very iconic narrator describes every action. If you’ve heard certain quotes floating around the internet, chances are they came from this game.

The core gameplay loop was simple: recruit a bunch of random-stat heroes, throw them through a trial by fire, and hope a few come out with good pros and minimal cons. The rest? “Letting go.” I remember a quote from Rock Paper Shotgun: “You have to play this game like an HR manager if you want to excel.” That sentence alone tells you exactly the mindset you need, because the game doesn’t show an ounce of mercy with some of the worst RNG encounters I’ve ever seen.

So why am I talking so much about the first game before reviewing the second? Because DD2 keeps the core mechanics almost identical—but improves a lot more. Here’s how:


---

1. Major visual upgrade

The graphics are massively improved. The characters feel present instead of cut-out animations, yet the devs still preserved the original art style. Everything is more beautiful—and more horrifying—at the same time.

2. Heroes are no longer disposable clones

You’re not just managing random faces you can throw away anymore. Each hero exists as an individual character with their own identity. This opens the door to a “backstory” mechanic, which ties directly into unlocking their unique skills.

3. A new travel system with the Stagecoach

Instead of selecting a dungeon and side-scrolling through it, you’re always moving through stages on a Stagecoach. This introduces path choices that affect your run, rewards, suffering, and even your ability to collect “Hope” (the currency that lets you “fail better” next time).


---

These are the big changes you’ll notice immediately. But there’s another major one fans will spot right away: the behavior system.

In the first game, when a hero hit max stress, they’d gain a Resolve state—good or bad—based on RNG, and you could later remove bad quirks by tossing them into the Sanitarium. But in DD2, you can only remove negative traits during Field Hospital encounters, which are not guaranteed to appear at the end of each region. This adds even more tension, since stress and quirks stack up with no guaranteed reset button.

I’ve seen many hardcore fans express disappointment because these changes remove the opportunity to create hilarious setups like the infamous “Gang of Crusaders” or the “Pain Train”—broken but fun duplicate-hero teams. In DD2, duplicates are no longer allowed.

Despite that, the game is still as unforgiving as you remember. But I think they improved the gameplay loop significantly. It works especially well on Steam Deck (runs smooth as butter, by the way). It’s the kind of game you can pick up, fail horribly, put down, and come back to later. Rinse and repeat. Somehow you still feel like you’re progressing, even with all the glorious failure.

Regardless of reward. I just genuinely love my own cohort, carefully hand picked to make for a good contingent of war ready men and women, against a barely alive levy leftover from an army long forgotten. It feels nice. It tickles me well.  The music, in my opinion, is on par with the first game, but the first game will win any comparison when it comes to sound design in general - exception for the draggi ng of weapons, the gurgling laughter of your enemies and the cries of babies immediately afterwards your heroes get assaulted.

That being said, those are the only good things I have to say. It goes downhill from now.

First and foremost, the most popular hero and arguably the mascot of the game, the crusader is hidden behind a paywall. I would've been fine with the fire girl being a dlc - but two main game heroes from the old game, and one of them arguably the mascot of DD as a whole and probably the most popular vanilla hero in general? Behind a paywall? I was completely turned off at launch from the game because it didn't feature my boy. So buying it WAS a requirement. And now Abom is hidden behind a paywall? Abhorrent. You do get a new area - crimson court style - but give us the main game heroes and make new ones for the dlc, Duelist style. It's incredibly scummy to have beloved characters from the first game locked behind a paywall. I personally wouldn't have played dd2 at all had I not been able to buy my boy. Deus vult bro. 

second point, it's hard for no reason. I do mean this in a bad way. It seems like the developers went: 
"How do we make the game stand out from the first one?" "I know! Let's just make it artficially harder!" 
it was the same design choice as dark souls 2. I'm a big fan of ds2, but the enemy placement was extremely unfair and only there to make it arbitrarily harder. DD2 also suffers that issue. Enemies have bloated health pools, borderline busted combos and, thanks to how much slower and how much of a slog the game is (fights almost always take around 10-15 minutes, unless it's 3 enemies), it just makes you feel like you're not really doing much other than wasting your time. The sea area specifically is much harder than the rest. I had more success in the forest, the countryside with cannibals, the burning city and the warrens combined, in a failing run, than I ever did in the sea level. The enemies there have just about everything except burn. Shuffle, big health pools, a unique and impactful debuff, strong team comps, etc. So fuck you if you play leper and jester. Your jester needs to push your leper up front so he can do something. And then bam. Another push. Of course there's counter play - and I did have fun playing the game. But when most attacks do so little damage... what's even the point? Only on your side of course, the enemy will always top roll on damage rolls. And heals? They're limited. And always weaker than enemy heals. Lore reasons? You have to ration them throughout the run and the brigand doctor doesn't. Gameplay reasons? Lol git gud.

Starting out is way too sluggish. To get all your heroes abilities, you need 5 shrines. So you basically need to go through purposely bad roads to get to something that will allow you to team and character build better. I think that's stupid. With how many characters there are in the game, it will take you hours to get all abilities for just 1 - and god forbid you want a crusader support from the get go. And you are going for a strength build. DD2 suffers the exact opposite problem. You start really weak and have to force yourself to make probably bad choices you're not ready for just to probably have fun later on. The upgrade system though, with candles, i find really good. In my opinion, dd1 is a better game. Fights tend to go out faster, but they are at least not sluggish like they are in dd2. In dd1, you can slow them down with certain team comps. In dd2, if you try to rush, you will be punished for it, and even so, it will still take far more time than most modded bosses too. I think my umibozu and plague priest fights took around 9 minutes. A single encounter in the flaming city often takes me around 12. It's sluggish and you cannot do anything about it. In dd1, it snaps and goes by quickly if you want it to but you can force it to slow down. Plus the fact that dd1 has better mods, in my opinion better areas and heroes, and the fact that it's also a better rogueLITE, it's a superior game with just enough control for you to do as you wish. DD2 only offers one dish. And that's fine, maybe the dish was made well and i don't recognise the taste, so those that love that taste WILL love this game, but to me, it is an inferior product. So, this is a weird one. I picked up [i]Darkest Dungeon 2 [/i]hoping for a refined, tension-filled follow-up to the first game, but… wow, it really didn’t stick. The first game’s slow, punishing crawl through dungeons is replaced here by a road trip roguelike that feels half-baked. The stress and affliction systems are still there, but stripped of their suspense and weight. It markets itself as a “rogue-lite with tactical tension,” but it’s more like a tactical-lite with the tension dialed way down and some baffling dev choices. Sure, you’ve got the same grim Lovecraftian atmosphere and art style, but the gameplay loop lacks the same gripping edge. It’s not a good sequel, and as a roguelike-lite, it fails to measure up to the first game’s carefully calibrated systems. I'm sure I could grind it out (5 hours isn't that much tbf), but I don't really want to.

[b]⚱️ Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] Gothic painterly visuals. The hand-illustrated, 3D, grotesque character designs and environments are still phenomenal. Every background, monster, and hero portrait is carefully crafted to evoke a sense of dread and decay, with heavy use of muted colors, deep shadows, and visceral textures. Even when the gameplay drags, it’s hard not to admire the sheer artistry of the world, which manages to retain that signature [i]Darkest Dungeon [/i]vibe. I wish I knew more about art, but I think this is the most beautiful art style in any game.

[*]Streamlined combat. Battles are noticeably faster than the first game, which can be both a blessing and a curse. The fights are more digestible, and you’re less likely to get bogged down in overly long encounters. This can make the game easier to approach for newcomers or casual players, but it also removes much of the tension that made the original so addictive. It’s cleaner but at the expense of the original’s strategic depth.

[*]Persistent character roster. Carrying heroes across runs adds a sense of continuity, and some of your favorite characters from DD1 return. You can invest in them, see their quirks play out over multiple trips, and feel a little attachment as you manage stress, injuries, and abilities. That said, these returns are hollow—the roster is cut dramatically, many fan favorites are gone, and characters feel weaker and less distinct than before. 

[*]Creepy Lovecraftian atmosphere. The game still nails the grim, oppressive mood through lighting, monster design, and ambient sound. Fog, shadows, and grotesque details make you feel like you’re on a road trip through a nightmare, even if the gameplay itself fails to sustain tension. It’s easy to get lost in the aesthetic, which is arguably the one area where DD2 succeeds consistently, though it can’t carry the rest of the game on its own.

[*] Post-launch support. From what I've seen so far, the devs have continued to support the game with large patches and DLCs.
[/list]

[b]🪦 Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] UI is difficult to read and frustrating to navigate. The interface is cramped, icons are tiny, and there’s not a lot of hover or tooltip information. This makes it extremely hard to understand what your characters are doing, what abilities do, or how stress and buffs are stacking. Combined with the already steep learning curve, it makes managing your party more difficult than needed.

[*]Road trip loop feels shallow and tedious. The main “caravan” mechanic replaces dungeon crawling, but it’s repetitive and low-stakes. The navigational minigame with the carriage is more busywork than meaningful gameplay, and the stops you make along the route rarely feel consequential. Unlike the dungeon runs in the first game, where every decision carried risk and reward, the road trip loop lacks drama or suspense. It becomes a slog of low-stakes encounters rather than an engaging roguelike journey.

[*]Runs are long, draining, and fixed in difficulty. Unlike the first game, which offered short, exhilarating bursts of tension, DD2 runs feel punishingly long with little variation in the challenge. The first game had a beautifully calibrated rhythm—you could take careful, strategic runs or go for desperate high-risk runs for valuable loot. The stakes felt tangible, and surviving a dungeon made your party’s story feel earned. In DD2, that urgency is gone. Everything drags, decisions feel less impactful, and you aren't able to quit either mid-run. I'm also not a fan of the new loot and progression and how it's tied to a currency system.

[*]Deciding to leave behind hero investment and resource management. One of DD1’s strongest points was how much you cared about your heroes. When a character died, it could be heartbreaking; you named them, invested in their quirks, and shaped a story around their journey. In DD2, that investment evaporates. A death feels meaningless—you just shrug and restart the run with a new copy. There’s no reason form a narrative with them because you know they’ll return with the name next time. There's also no Hamlet :(

[*]Roster cut and weakened heroes. Many fan-favorite characters from DD1 are gone—Abomination, Arbalest, Crusader, Houndmaster, Musketeer, and Shieldbreaker, I believe. Returning characters feel weaker, too. But that might just be me.

[*]Arbitrary design restrictions. The game punishes heal-stalling or exploiting minor mechanics like having multiple of the same heros. It is a single-player game, so that tweak bugged me a bit. 
[/list]

I loved playing Darkest Dungeon 1, but Darkest Dungeon 2 is pretty bad.  And not in the sense of "it's not like DD1, therefore bad", but in the sense of as a standalone game, it's bad.

It's a confusing, "lol! Gotcha! FU!  Go grind again", RNG grindfest.

On the confusing part, you don't really know what's going on.  The UI is fairly bad.  Before an expedition, I wanted to change a path for one of my guys.  Must be in their character sheet, right?  Nope.  Changing a character's path is not in their character sheet, but somewhere else.  

In the beginning I did a multi-part quest to get the Crusader character unlocked.  Okay, that must be how I unlock the other characters.  After about 10 hours I didn't get any quest for other characters, so I googled it.  Well apparently you can just buy them outright, but nothing ever mentioned it.  You're supposed to just find out about it somehow.

These seem like a minor nitpick, but this happens all the time, especially when in combat you got SOME icon that applies to you/enemy but you don't know what it is.  It was surprisingly hard to find out what they do.

Also, before the expedition, you have an opportunity to buy things like items and wagon modifiers.  Why bother buying there when I could just find them during adventuring?  So I went about 20 hours before I (accidentally via google) found out that you need to purchase them here to have the potential to unlock them during your adventuring -- i..e you buy them to gain the opportunity to RNG them in future runs.  And there are hundreds of items, so the more you get, the more RNG you have to conquer to get what you want.  

You also don't retain items between runs.  Yep, you start from scratch.  Because screw you and your time.

Speaking of bad UI, there's tutorial popups that you can click on to learn about the game.  However, if there's more than one popup at the same time and you click on one, ALL of them go away -- including the ones you didn't click on.   Did you memorize the topics for the other ones?  No?  Lol, screw you.

In combat, if you blink at the wrong time you miss something that happened.  Or maybe you have a question on what roll and modifiers just happened.  Well, look no further, because screw you.  You ain't seeing it.  There's no log or details of what happened.

In addition to the grindfest for items, I grinded out the right quirks (and got rid of the negative ones) over 10 hours.  Then I swapped out one of my characters for a new one.  It didn't work well and that new guy died.  Realizing I wouldn't be able to make it to the next checkpoint, I decided to just end the expedition and return before everyone else died.  Lol!  Screw you!  All quirks you've been grinding for 10 hours gone -- there's no warning or explanation that would happen.  Returning with 3/4 characters alive is literally the same as a party wipe!

But that's not the only way you get screwed.  Want to fight a boss and didn't google it beforehand to find the "correct" party composition?  Lol!  Screw you and your 10 hours grinding.  Grind it again noob.  Have a balanced party that was fine for everything until you wanted to try whatever was in the library?  Lol screw you!  This boss requires all back row damage!  Now go back and regrind those 10 hours and make sure to google every boss beforehand you noob.

You may think, "well just save the game before something risky".  Lol!  Screw you.  There are no saves.  You can't go back.  If you spent 10 hours grinding something and just lose it all due to horrible game mechanics, stay screwed noob.

That's when I uninstalled.

And that's the bottom line of why this game is bad: the developers do not respect the player's time.  All the grinding, random RNG, confusion are carefully designed to screw over your time.  It's like they realized the game is too short if you retained these things, so they brainstormed ways to screw you over and force you to regrind just to make the game a decent length.

Do not get this game if you actually value your time.

The devs have said in interviews that they were burnt out of Darkest Dungeon from all the time they spent developing the first game. It shows, because while the first game was difficult, it was still fun. There was a feeling of making progress in the game even when it was absolutely killing you. The gameplay loop was simple, but there was a lot of depth to the combat and the way you went about fights. They've eliminated pretty much everything that made the first game good. 

The systems in this game aren't fun to interact with. The relationship system sucks. People start hating each other and then they make each other's skills put debuffs on each other. So if one person uses the skill that's randomly chosen when the negative relationship starts, the other person gets a debuff, like being blinded or gaining a point of stress. The stress system is worse now. Hitting 100 stress in the first game was rough since the character might begin acting on their own, using a skill you don't want them to or just not hitting the target you were going to have them hit. In this game, they just instantly drop to around 10% hp and cause their relationship with everyone to drop by 3 points, which is a lot. Combat is less fun as well. Almost every fight I get into has enemies applying dodge or block to themselves constantly. It feels like the devs were far too focused on making a difficult game and forgot that it's supposed to be fun as well. They've also arbitrarily stopped you from being able to heal from most skills unless the target is below 50% or 33% hp. Sure, you heal passively while riding around in the stage coach, so you don't need to try and micromanage hp all the time in fights, but you still want to be able to stop people from getting too low in fights to begin with. 

There are some good things I like about the game as well. One of which being the healing while riding in the stage coach. The art direction of the game is good. I think that the 3D models are great. Having more story behind the characters is nice. There's definitely a bigger focus on story telling for the narrator and the characters behind each of the classes. I think it's a nice touch for building on the overall lore of the world in addition to the story of the game. I think the UI for the game is really nice. There were some small things I wasn't a big fan of when I first saw it, but I got used to it pretty quickly and enjoy it now. 

Overall, I would recommend just not playing this game. I don't think it matters much whether you've played the first game or not. If you want a fun but difficult turn-based game, there are much better ones out there. This game is a lot of style and not a lot of substance. I still want to see more out of the world and lore of the game, I just hope it's in a better game next time.

Darkest Dungeon 1 was great because it constantly tempted you back despite all the hardship and frustration. Darkest Dungeon 2 doesn't do any of that. It's boring and repetitive and constantly presents you with fully hopeless situations where the only thing to do is die and start over. In the first one, the stakes made you want to keep trying, even if it felt impossible, because the difference between success and failure was so great. #2 is just dice rolls and Aborts. This game sucks. I uninstalled Darkest Dungeon 1 many times, after returning to it like one of the cursed "heroes," because the allure and the fear were balanced, like in the world of the game. I will uninstall Darkest Dungeon 2 exactly once, right now, because it is boring.

So, DD2. The game's kinda bad. At least the main gamemode, Confessions. 

Confessions is generally not super good, since it's run structure is extremely repetetive with barely any change to differentiate between runs. You build a team, then stay with that team for 2-3h. During the run, your playstyle barely changes, meaning you'll likely feel that every fight just feels the same, with pretty much every hero having a designated "opener button" which you will press on the first turn for 90% of fights. The entire team also just functions the same at the start of the run and the end of the run, since mastery often just upgrades your numbers and Trinkets don't do enough to change your playstyle. This means a team at the Crossroads will just have less numbers, but the same playstyle as a Mountain-ready team after 3h of playtime. All of this results in a very repetetive grindfest that feels unbelievably similar to the last run. 

The meta progression also isn't very good. Not being able to see what you actually unlock is probably my main gripe, since you cannot see which skills you will unlock down the line, only leaving you to see the first 5 skills you start with. The same applies to Trinkets/Paths/Stagecoach gear etc etc. This is a really bad feeling, since you basically have to watch a starting guide somewhere, since without a good start getting more candles quicker will be more difficult, mainly bc you don't have the good unlocks to get good runs, which give more meta progression. This is on top of some unlockable Trinkets and items being extremely bad, cluttering the pool from allowing you to find your actually good Trinkets. 

The game also runs into it's predecessors issue of not telling you shit. Some mechanics aren't explained, the glossary doesn't update when the token in question changes it's effects and the tutorials are one long textwall you have to read through, often even with outdated screenshots. This wouldn't be a big issue, but losing a run 2h deep to a mechanic the game never tells you about just feels extremely bad. 

The Boss design is also baffling. Some Bosses basically need specific things to beat, which you have to build around. The issue? Well, you have to bring those things at THE START OF THE RUN WITH NO INDICATION DURING THE RUN YOU NEED THOSE THINGS. This often leads you to just not having the correct team to beat a boss, which means 2-3h of playtime down the drain. 
Another issue is that the Bosses have "Dark-Souls Boss design", aka you need to make mistakes, learn from those mistakes and then build your team better for that specific boss until you figure out the way to counter them. In Dark Souls, that's the attack patterns and dodge timing, in DD2, that's teambuilding and Items. Small issue, the walkway to try again at the boss is 2-3h long. This leads to an unecessary amount of waitng to try again at a boss, only to see that your planned strategy actually doesn't counter the boss and you losing all that progress. This just means you should look up a Boss guide, since otherwise you'll be wasting loads of time trial-and-erroring at the Boss. 

The main system of the game is also extremely snowbally. Relationships tend to win you the run by generating an insane amount of recovery/tokens, but can also do the same in the negative sense, losing you the run with crippling +Stress or negative tokens. This means you either know what you are doing, get good relationships early and cruise through the run, or struggle early and get clapped by half your skills generating Blind suddenly. If you get the hang of it, it feels great, but to get the hang of it, you need to get gud first, which is very difficult with the negative relationships.

There is some good stuff though. 

The path system essentially gives each hero 4 playstyles, which allows for some creative teambuilding. Of course, not all 4 paths are made equal, but a lot of the fun is taking a bad path/playstyle, building around it and then trying to make it work. This CAN be fun, but heavily depends on what you like doing. I personally like running these weird, off-meta comps, but that's not everybody's cup of tea. 

The token system tends to be more reliable than DD1's pure numbers. Being able to plan ahead like in DD2 is a really cool way of allowing people to express skill, instead of just being bailed out by a random dodge. There IS still RNG, but it's much less overbearing than in the first game. 

Kingdoms. If you noticed, all my negative stuff was only really applicable to Confessions. Kingdoms doesn't have meta-progression and while it does take longer, the final Bosses aren't an all-in fight like in Confessions. You actually get multiple tries to learn the Bosses' mechanics within one run, which is really nice. The Trinkets are still a bit hit or miss, but since you can keep them out of the drop pool by putting them into Inn storages, you can usually get something good. It also allowing much more access to a shop to specifically buy the good stuff, since then the cluttered garbage can just get ignored and you can just get to the good stuff. The relationships are still very snowbally, but being able to just ignore a really bad relationship by swapping that hero out mid-run for a new one, then getting that hero back after you have items to fix that bad relationship also makes it much easier to avoid snowballing into 4 bad relationship on an unplayable team. 
The one gripe about Kingdoms will always be it's extremely steep learning curve. Since you HAVE to manage your resources well from the start, you could just waste a bunch of important materials on upgrades you don't need, which leads to a worse midgame, which leads to an even worse lategame. This and essentially having 8-12 heroes at your disposal at the same time basically means you have to have some experience with all of them to have a shot at actually winning the run. Outside of that, Kingdoms is a really really good mode. 

Now, in conclusion, should you buy DD2? Well, not really unless you are willing to grind Confessions until you have learned most of the heroes to swap to the actually good Kingdoms mode, which will take a LOT of hours to fully unlock each hero to learn them. The other option is to watch someone who has experience in the game, learning from them without actually playing the game and then immediately jumping into Kingdoms. If the devs deleted confessions and instead made a tutorial kingdoms module that allowed you to experiment a bit with all of the heroes, this would easily be a positive review, but with the bad gamemode dragging down the learning experience with insane amounts of grinding and unrewarding boss design, attached to the good gamemode essentially being skill-locked with it's overwhelming amount of learning needed, it just ends up being a negative review.

It’s difficult for me to write a negative review for this game — but here we are. I’m a huge fan of the original Darkest Dungeon. It’s one of my favorite games of all time, and naturally, I kept comparing DD2 to it. But that’s not really fair. these two games are very different. So, I decided to judge DD2 as its own title.

And yet, even when treated as a standalone experience, I still have to leave a negative review.

If you don’t own the first game — buy that one instead. If you already do and want more of that experience, check out the incredible mods made by the community. Darkest Dungeon II is not Darkest Dungeon.

My first problem is bad game design.

Let’s start with the most glaring issue: the grind.
The game only begins to feel like a roguelite once you’ve unlocked nearly everything — but to get there, you’ll need an absurd amount of candles. Each “Confession” run can take anywhere from 2 to 6 hours (yes, really), and the upgrades you unlock are often mediocre or even detrimental. Every new trinket you add to the pool dilutes your chances of getting something actually useful, and there’s no way to ban unwanted items from appearing.

Then there’s the token system — possibly the worst offender.
Combat may technically rely less on RNG now, but the token mechanics make it insufferable. Enemies can use any skill from any position, and most of those skills either pile negative tokens on your heroes or stack buffs like Evasion endlessly. The player doesn’t get the same luxury and often has to waste turns managing tokens instead of actually fighting.

Stuns are a joke — you need to pass two resistance checks to pull one off, while enemies can stun your heroes freely. Taunt tokens? Enemies sometimes just ignore them. Meanwhile, stress constantly hovers over your party like a curse. You can only reduce it mid-battle once it’s above 5/10, which feels punishing and unnecessary.

Add to that the relationship system, which becomes a chore. Outside of inns, you can’t meaningfully manage relationships, and when things go bad, someone inevitably becomes the scapegoat to concentrate all of the negative reactions from your team. Over long runs (again — 2 to 6 hours!), losing a hero usually means you’re done for. And negative relationships highly increase the likelyhood of that.

And honestly, this is only half of the design issues. I’ll spare you the rest, since there are already plenty of YouTubers who’ve dissected the game’s flaws in detail.

My second problem is the story

I’m usually considered a “lore guy.” I love diving into the story and piecing together the world — but Darkest Dungeon II makes that almost impossible. The story exists, I guess, but it’s scattered and barely coherent.

There are no item descriptions, no lore entries, no real sense of world-building. You only get occasional comments from the Academic, which start to make some sense by the final confession — but even then, it’s thin. We never learn what happened to the cities, who the minibosses are, or even what most of the confessions bosses are.

Yes, I understand it’s supposed to be Lovecraftian — fear of the unknown and all that. But even the unknown needs a foundation. In the first game, and this is the only time when I will make such a comparison as I think it is apropriate, we knew why the Ancestor did what he did. We understood that he created many of the horrors, and even the greater beings beyond him had their place in the world’s logic. Notes, trinket descriptions, and boss lore tied it all together.

In DD2, there’s almost nothing. The only thing we truly learn about is “The Body of Work.” Even the hero shrine stories are retreads of the short comics released for the first game.

As for positives - I’ll give credit where it’s due: the visuals, animations, music, and sound design are phenomenal. The art team, composer, and sound designers truly outdid themselves. They’re the reason I managed to enjoy parts of my time with this game at all.

As a side note - I also waited to play the full Kingdoms module before writing this review. It’s certainly better than the Confessions mode — much better, in fact — but it still suffers from the same core design problems, especially the token system.

If you really want to give Darkest Dungeon II a try, go ahead — there are moments of brilliance here and there. But if you came for the spirit of Darkest Dungeon, you’ll be disappointed.

[h1] 4/10 - A step backwards for the series [/h1]

As a huge fan of Darkest Dungeon 1, I avoided this sequel for years due to the mixed reception on release. Having given them two years to expand and bugfix and seeing the reviews shift to Mostly Positive, I decided to follow the advice of the positive review givers and give DD2 a try with an open mind, letting go of my preconceptions of what DD1 was and allowing it to be its own, new, different game. Unfortunately after playing a few runs it has quickly become clear that these new and different changes are overwhelmingly bad, and I don't think that's my bias as a DD1 enjoyer speaking. Almost all the new mechanics and additions are either extremely grindy, heavily RNG-based, deeply derivative, or just plain old frustrating and unfun, and the abscence of many charming and useful features from the first game are sorely missed. 

[h2] The Good [/h2]

+ Voice Acting/Sound Design. This is a shoe in for DD2, featuring the late and great Wayne June reprising his role as the iconic narrator. Music and sound is on point as always and add a lot to the atmosphere.

+ Writing and Character Lore. This is basically the only thing in my opinion that DD2 truly does better than DD1. DD1 had good writing, but DD2 really leans into the character backstories and lore, featuring new 'shrines' you can explore to delve into the hero's pasts and the traumas that made them who they are, featuring special dream combats. These are really fun, like a better version of the shieldbreaker's dream trauma thingys from the first game. Probably the best new feature of the entire game.

+ Artstyle. This is another shoe in. DD2 maintains the series' distinctive and striking artstyle, a gorgeous blend of lovecraftian fantasy raging against the withered humanism of its unlikely but determined heroes. Things look great in the new 3d artstyle, and I'd say that things are generally more striking, dynamic, and fully rendered than in the first game, giving DD2 an edge in the art department (although I still think the Crimson Court is the single best looking area between both games). The new areas are visually interesting and beautiful, from the burning city to the twisted forests, it all looks great. This is where the negatives start showing up though, because DD2 has significantly less enemies and locations than the first game, while simultaneously expecting much, MUCH more playtime from you. That means that art and enemies start repeating much faster and harder than the first game, and you'll have to fight the same things over and over and over again. Despite looking better, it gets tiresome much faster than DD1.

[h2] The Bad [/h2]

- Grind. Everything is a million times slower. It takes forever to do anything and after two full 2 hour runs it has become clear the game expects me to do like 5 more of these (10 hours) before I can even unlock the most basic of character features and effective consumables. It seems like game developers these days are trending towards being less and less respectful of player time and DD2 is unfortunately a great example of devs with a fun formula just streeeeeeeeeeeeeetching it out as thin as possible to juice out everything they can get from their players without doing hard stuff like making new content or modes. This game has noticeably less content than DD1 but demands like 20x the playtime. 

- Setting Lore. Despite having better character backstories and more fleshed out, quality writing for its heroes, the binding lore of DD2 is much, much worse than the first game, which is really annoying, because the actual core idea of the top line lore is still excellent but the execution is just terrible. Where in DD1 you're a distant noble cousin brought to the ancestor's estate to fight evil lurking below, in DD2 you're an academic on a quest to destroy the evil artifact you accidentally brought into the world that is destroying it. So what's the problem? The lore in DD2 is COMPLETELY disconnected from its gameplay. 

In DD1, as the noble heir, you manage your estate, recruit heroes who show up hearing rumors of riches, and plan expeditions to the depths. When you lose a run, those heroes are dead and your work continues without them at the estate. In DD2, as the protege, you summon a magic carriage from hell imbued with the physical essence of the last hope of humanity, summoning heroes gacha-style through a magic portal to fight horrors on the way to the mountain, and whenever those heroes die you are teleported into the multiverse to enter a new dimension where you summon your magic carriage and magic gacha heroes with another, new physical essence of the last hope of humanity to try again. This fucking sucks. It's the kind of lazy, disconnected writing that clearly only exists as an excuse to get the player into the gameplay loop as quickly as possible, the kind of slop you'd expect from a mobile game that practically demands you not think too hard about it. Incredibly, incredibly dissapointing. 

- RNG. Now, RNG has always been a major element of Darkest Dungeon, but in this game it's so much worse than it was in DD1. Whereas deaths in DD1 were almost always due to a combination of bad luck and ineffective planning causing you to trip into a death spiral, you can literally just randomly get fucked off the bat at any time for absolutely nothing in your control in DD2. HP pools are smaller, enemy damage is swingier, and much, MUCH less is in your control. Trinkets are no longer meta-progressed but completely randomly generated each run. Relationships randomly appear impacting random abilities between characters. Afflictions randomly appear and cannot be removed unless you randomly stumble across a field hospital with enough gold at that exact moment to deal with it (remember when you could send heroes to the sanitarium in the hamlet between runs?) Many enemies can either kill or stressbomb full HP/0 stress heroes in one turn if you get particularly unlucky - and while this was possible in DD1, it's downright *common* in DD2. And since it's a multi region formula, if you get fucked in region 1 or 2, you're just fucked. If a random set of crits kills your DPS before your plague doctor gets their turn, or if you generate a negative relationship that causes your most important ability to make your tank vulnerable or your DPS weakened, your run is over. Basically every aspect of Darkest Dungeon 2 is far more dependant on RNG than its predecessor, and this increased dependency on luck serves to make the game considerably more frustrating and less skill based.

[h2] The Ugly [/h2]

- Relationship system. I really like the idea of this system actually. But in practice it's just fucking awful. As mentioned above, this is a purely RNG based system, where player impact is EXTREMELY limited.

- Metaprogression. Metaprogression still exists in DD2 but it is objectively worse in every way than it was in DD1. Metaprogression is less permanent, less impactful, and less fun, despite there being a lot, LOT more of it. In DD1, maybe you upgrade your hero's sword or armor, or find a good trinket that enables a strong build. Cool, now you can do harder runs. In DD2, you unlock one of like 250 trinkets (1-2 candles apiece, you earn maybe 30 on a good 2 hour run), most of which are awful and totally useless, and hope that one of the good ones shows up on your run to make it not suck. Oh, or you can spend 5 candles to give one hero +5% death's door resistance only for them to die on the first check anyway. Some of the trinkets you can unlock don't suck, but this metaprogression system absolutely does. If DD1 was chipping through the mines to go back to the hamlet and upgrade your pickaxe, DD2 is chipping through the mines to go back to the crossroads and get 1/10th of a respirator that has a 5% chance of showing up on your run to prevent some of the charcoal fumes, sometimes. It is much slower, much less impactful, and just awful.
